author: ryanleeschneider
content: Has there been any discussion to start requiring EIP-155 protections on all txs in an upcoming hard fork?  I honestly never noticed it was still optional.

author: karalabe
content: We need to slowly phase out non eip-155

author: karalabe
content: Geth started rejecting them on the RPC

author: karalabe
content: this should allow people to adjust (can be disabled via a flag) without causing downtime

author: karalabe
content: our next step will probably be stopping forwarding such transactions **if** they drop below some meaningful rate

author: karalabe
content: then we can drop via consensus

author: karalabe
content: but we shouldn't really pull the rug from underneath people that are unaware and still use old sigs

author: .vbuterin
content: Agree on phasing out non-eip155

author: ryanleeschneider
content: I guess EIP-1559 will also hopefully go a long way to reducing the prevalence of non-EIP-155 txs since presumably most people will want to move to the new format for the potential gas savings and the chainId is baked into the payload.  Maybe popular enough that merged eth1/2 could only allow EIP-2718 typed txs so new mempool implementations dont need to worry about supporting the legacy format? ðŸ¤ž
